title: Rustc incorrectly suggests adding an bound that exists in the where clause to call a method on an external trait with an arbitrary self type
body:
Given this code:

```rust
use std::future::Future;

struct Wrapper<T>(T);
impl<T> Wrapper<T>
where
    T: Future,
{
    fn run(mut self) {
        self.0.poll(todo!())
    }
}
```

Rust emits this error:

```
error[E0599]: no method named `poll` found for type parameter `T` in the current scope
 --> src/lib.rs:9:16
  |
9 |         self.0.poll(todo!())
  |                ^^^^ method not found in `T`
  |
  = help: items from traits can only be used if the type parameter is bounded by the trait
help: the following trait defines an item `poll`, perhaps you need to restrict type parameter `T` with it:
  |
4 | impl<T: Future> Wrapper<T>
  |      ^^^^^^^^^
```

This error doesn't make sense because the `Future` bound is already present.

Note that if the trait with the arbitrary `self` type is local, the error message is correct:

```
error[E0599]: no method named `poll` found for type parameter `T` in the current scope
  --> src/lib.rs:13:16
   |
4  |     fn run(self: Pin<&mut Self>);
   |                   -------------- the method might not be found because of this arbitrary self type
...
13 |         self.0.run();
   |                ^^^^ method not found in `T`
   |
```

### Meta
<!--
If you're using the stable version of the compiler, you should also check if the
bug also exists in the beta or nightly versions.
-->

`rustc --version --verbose`:
```
rustc 1.51.0-nightly (d1aed50ab 2021-01-26)
binary: rustc
commit-hash: d1aed50ab81df3140977c610c5a7d00f36dc519f
commit-date: 2021-01-26
host: x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu
release: 1.51.0-nightly
LLVM version: 11.0.1
```

This also occurs on stable 1.49.0.
